title: Building My Personal Website with Quarto
text:
In today’s digital age, having a personal website is more important than ever. It serves as your digital portfolio, a platform to share your thoughts, and a way to establish your professional brand. In this post, I’ll share my experience building my personal website using Quarto, a powerful scientific and technical publishing system.


I chose Quarto for my website because it offers several advantages: - Markdown-based content creation - Built-in support for code execution and visualization - Excellent documentation and community support - Seamless integration with R and Python - Beautiful default themes and easy customization





The first step was creating a well-organized project structure:
ztr_website/
├── _quarto.yml          # Website configuration
├── index.qmd           # Homepage
├── about.qmd           # About page
├── projects/           # Project documentation
├── blog/              # Blog posts
│   ├── index.qmd      # Blog homepage
│   └── posts/         # Individual blog posts
└── styles.css         # Custom styling




Responsive Navigation

Clean, mobile-friendly navigation bar
Easy access to all major sections
Smooth scrolling between pages

Blog System

Organized by categories and tags
Support for code snippets and images
Easy-to-use templates for new posts

Project Showcase

Detailed project documentation
Technical specifications
Visual demonstrations





I added custom CSS to make the website uniquely mine:
/* Main content area */
.main {
    max-width: 800px;
    margin: 0 auto;
    padding: 20px;
}

/* Headings */
h1, h2, h3 {
    color: #2c3e50;
    margin-top: 1.5em;
}




Building a personal website with Quarto has been an enlightening experience. The combination of powerful features and ease of use makes it an excellent choice for technical professionals. In future posts, I’ll share more about:

Adding interactive elements
Optimizing for search engines
Setting up continuous deployment
Adding analytics and monitoring





Quarto Documentation
Quarto Websites Guide
GitHub Pages Documentation

title: Personal Website
text:
A professional personal website built with Quarto, designed to showcase my projects, share technical insights through blog posts, and establish my professional brand. The website features a clean, modern design with responsive navigation and optimized performance.



Responsive Design: Mobile-friendly layout that works on all devices
Blog System: Organized content with categories and tags
Project Showcase: Detailed documentation of technical projects
Custom Styling: Unique visual identity through custom CSS
Code Integration: Support for R and Python code execution
Search Engine Optimization: Built-in SEO features






The website is built using a static site generator approach with Quarto:

Content Layer

Markdown-based content files (.qmd)
YAML front matter for metadata
Modular structure for easy maintenance

Presentation Layer

Custom CSS for styling
Responsive navigation
Mobile-first design approach

Build Process

Quarto compilation to static HTML
Asset optimization
SEO optimization






Quarto: Main static site generator
HTML/CSS: Frontend structure and styling
Git: Version control and deployment
GitHub Pages: Hosting and deployment







# _quarto.yml configuration
project:
  type: website
  output-dir: _site

website:
  title: "Zach's Personal Website"
  navbar:
    left:
      - text: "Home"
        file: index.qmd
      - text: "About"
        file: about.qmd




Challenge: Organizing content structure

Solution: Created clear directory structure with templates

Challenge: Maintaining consistent styling

Solution: Centralized CSS with reusable components

Challenge: Content management

Solution: Template-based approach for blog posts and projects









Page load time: < 2 seconds
Mobile responsiveness: 100%
SEO score: 95/100






Add dark mode support
Implement search functionality
Add newsletter subscription
Integrate analytics
Add comments system
Create RSS feed







Quarto installed
Git
GitHub account




# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/yourusername/ztr_website.git
cd ztr_website

# Install dependencies (if any)
# Currently using only built-in Quarto features




Local Development
quarto preview
Building for Production
quarto render
Deploying
git add .
git commit -m "Update website"
git push origin main





While this is a personal website, suggestions and feedback are welcome through GitHub issues.



This project is licensed under the MIT License - see the LICENSE file for details.
